territory.notes: In the 1850s, U.S., German, and British settlers on Samoa began lobbying their respective countries to annex Samoa. In 1899, the United States annexed Eastern Samoa, referred to as American Samoa. In the same year, Germany annexed Western Samoa, which it controlled until 1914, at which time it fell under New Zealand’s control. In 1962, Western Samoa gained its independence and in 1997, dropped the ‘Western’ appellation, officially changing its name to Independent State of Samoa.
